Title: Prove that $\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{f(x^2)-f(0)}{x}=0$ if $f:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$ is differentiable at $x=0$
AcceptedAnswer:
Recall the chain rule, 
$$
\left(f(g(x))\right)'=f'(g(x))g'(x)
$$
here $g(x)=x^2$, and 
$$
\lim_{x\to 0}\frac{f(g(x))-f(g(0))}{x}=f'(g(0))(g'(0))=f'(0)\cdot 0=0
$$
